title: Teaching kids about money
summary: It's important that children grow up to be prudent managers of their own money, including learning how to save diligently.
tag-2: It's important that children grow up to be prudent managers of their own money, including learning how to save diligently.
tag-3: And yet this is a mighty tough skill to teach. Kids grow up spending their parents' money, which means everything is free to them--and there is no incentive to curb their desires.
tag-4: What to do? Here are four strategies that you might try with your children:
tag-5: Play the soda game. When you go to restaurants, offer your kids a choice: They can have a soda or they can have $1. Suddenly, their choice has financial consequences--and you might be surprised by how much water they drink.
tag-6: More pocket money less frequently. Instead of giving your kids $5 pocket money each week, give them $65 every three months. The larger sum will seem more precious and make them think harder about their purchases. And because the money has to last three months, they will be compelled to budget.
tag-7: Open a bank account. Help your children set up a savings or checking account and then deposit their pocket money into the account. That way, your children are more likely to feel like they are spending their own money. After all, instead of asking you for cash, they will need to ask themselves--and then head down to the bank.
tag-8: Talk about your own struggles. Today, your children may enjoy a comfortable existence in a middle-class home. But there's a good chance they will struggle financially when they first join the work force--and you may want to prepare your kids by talking about any of your own struggles when you were new to the work world.
tag-9: Indeed, financial values are often passed down to our children in the stories we tell. These stories can be far more powerful than any lecture you could deliver on the virtues of financial prudence.
